participants.participant: José Ignacio Sanchez Galán, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
José Luis del Valle, Chief Executive Officer, ScottishPower
José Sáinz Armada, Chief Financial Officer
Xabier Viteri, Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola Renovables

plist.p: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Thanks very much for coming today. Let's begin with the results of the 2007 fiscal year. We have a very tight agenda. So we're going to divide this presentation into three parts. First, we'll talk about the Group results and then Renovables, and then we'll have the Q&A session. The mother company, Iberdrola -- and between the Iberdrola results and the Renovables, we'll take our coffee break.

Good morning, everyone. First of all, I would like to thank those that are listening through the webpage and those that are here in person for your interest in the company. Today, as always, we have José Sáinz Armada, the Director of Finance; Luis San Pedro, Director of Operations; and Luis del Valle, as you know, is CEO of ScottishPower and other operations within the Group.

The results -- Group results will be structured as follows. On the one hand, I'm going to take a look at the results of 2007. Then, José Luis del Valle is going to talk about the major aspects of the financial situation of ScottishPower. Then, José Sáinz Armada will do our financial results of the Group result. And then, I'll come back with some conclusions.

Now, the net benefit of Iberdrola has a record, which is almost 42% increase over 2006. This growth is based on the operational results of 42.4% increase in EBITDA. Together, with the solid evolution of traditional business of Iberdrola in 2007, we have also carried out three operations, which have consolidated the company as one of the main energy companies in the world -- the integration of ScottishPower, the going public of Renovables, and Energy East in the United States.

In terms of ScottishPower in the Group has -- this has concluded with success and in a record time. In just over eight months, this is both a financial success, 1.3 billion EBITDA, which is 25% of the Group results from the strategic point of view. In this sense, we should point out that in addition to the fundamental contribution of the other parts of its business, ScottishPower has contributed its renewable assets in the UK and the United States.

Hence, this segregation and merger situation of this business in the Group, we have managed to put Renovables on the stock market. It's the number one wind energy company in the world. And it's number seven on the IBEX. Iberdrola has also been able to carry out these operations at record time and situating its leverage at 42.4% as -- and as a result, the rating agents have given the company an "A" rating.

And finally, I wanted to point out that once with this capital -- after the capital increase, the profit per shares has increased by 14% in 2007, which is more than the average of the 2000/2006 period. Therefore, the operations carried out have had a positive impact in terms of profit per share from the very first year.

Now, in terms of the major points in 2007, Iberdrola has diversified its business. Production has increased by 34%, up to more than 120,000 GWh, and with an increase of distributed energy by 25% to 160,000 GW. So these figures only account Energy East and PPM as of April, just eight months.

Also, ScottishPower has diversified its mix -- production mix. And Iberdrola with the thermal and wind energy, has done this in the UK and the United States markets, which are now 19% of the total of our production.

Now, Spain has reduced its relative weight from 80% in 2006 to 54% in 2007, which shows that the internationalization process has been very successful over this past year. Indeed, Iberdrola now is a more international group and a stronger group and, in 2007, has an EBITDA over €5.5 billion.

Also, could I comment on the contributions in the UK and the US with just eight months, 26% of the total, and this complements a solid position of Iberdrola in Spain and in Latin America. In 2008, we expect the international business in EBITDA to pass 50% in EBITDA.

In terms of operational expenses, the company continues to be efficient and making efficiency one of its major, major issues. In this expansion period, the increase in our gross margin is 1.25 times the operational expenses, showing that efficiency has increased by 6%.

As I said before, eight months after having closed the operation with ScottishPower and just a little bit more than a year after announcing it, the situation of the company has been -- the merger has been a major success.

I'd also like to talk about the contribution of the workers of this Scottish company, which have blended very well into the company, with results that are now 25% of the total results of the Group, and a unified management system for everyone, and the work on the acceleration and synergies and saving -- cost savings.

So I'd also like to thank them and their Spanish colleagues, which have also made a considerate effort, and they've worked side by side to benefit on both sides. ScottishPower in terms of its assets in renewables in the US and the UK has been key in this second axis -- strategic axis.

The going public of Renovables with more than 7,700 installed MW -- almost 8,000 now. This is the number one company in the world in this sector and has a fantastic prospectus for the future based, on the one hand, with a portfolio of more than 42,000 MW, and in terms of access to the best machinery guaranteeing through contracts with the major suppliers, and is the number one player in this business. So it has tremendous efficiency in that regard.

On a record time, we've been able to reorder and split companies and integrate human teams and gone public in just six months. Just a few weeks ago, this company also formed part of the IBEX-35, where it is now the number seventh Spanish company for capitalization.

In terms of the development of authorization for the takeover of Energy East, we are complying with the timetable that we announced at the beginning of the operation. We have all of the federal permits. And the only state permit that we need is from the State of New York, and that process is underway. So we hope to be able to complete this operation by the middle of 2008.

Also, in 2007, we've invested more than €25 billion. And therefore, the balance sheet of the company has doubled to €68 billion, reinforcing our financial solidity. And finally, the increase of 42% in net profit and 47% in operational cash flow, reaching almost €4 billion, is 14% of the profit and 18% of the cash flow per average shares showing, therefore, the operations have had positive impact on the bottomline this year.
Now, I'm going to give the floor to José Luis del Valle, who's going to talk about the results of ScottishPower.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman. When we announced the Iberdrola ScottishPower, we talked about synergies and other operational cost reductions for €130 billion by the third year in addition to €45 million per year for four or five years in terms of savings and investments.

These objectives have now been increased to 204 and €62 million, respectively, as a result of the efforts made by our teams in the UK and in Spain to transfer our best practices in both directions, as our chairman has just mentioned.

Now, through each quarter in 2007, we have been observing this favorable development of the costs that we're able to control, both in terms of personnel and external services, which have fallen by 7.6% as a result of the efficiency measures taken -- both at the corporate headquarters where we've had a decrease of 30%, and in terms of commercial expenses which is where we're now having greater profitability, while at the same time optimizing the customer portfolio, which has been maintained above 5.2 million.

Also being implemented, we have 61 projects of all types with a view to cut costs by €160 million by 2010. And we have already achieved, in 2007, reductions, which year-on-year, are more than €30 million. In terms of commercial expenses, we have reduced costs, while at the same time enhancing operational and financial variables.

Operationally speaking, we've had less claims by Energywatch by 61%, and the customer satisfaction index has increased to 66% according to Uswitch. We have also been the number one company in the UK in complying with our obligations and commitments for energy efficiency. And financially, we've reduced by 13% the amount of time for doubtful payments.

Now, we've also maintained a level of thermal production, despite the programmed outages at our plants to carry out environmental improvements, and especially, the installation of the desulphur plant at the Longannet coal power plant.

Now, in terms of the grid, we've also improved costs. We're now in the first percentile -- 25% percentile in terms of efficiency, while at the same time, reducing the interruptions in the grid by 13% that is improving reliability of the grid.

Now just briefly, I'm going to now talk about the timetable of operations for our Energy East project. As the Chairman has mentioned, we have achieved the four federal authorizations required and from the States of Connecticut, New Hampshire and Maine. We only need now the authorization from the State of New York, which we hope to achieve before the end of the first half of 2008, thus, complying with the timetable that we had announced.

Now, our request is, now at arbitration stage before the Administrative Judge and the technical services of the Pubic Commission Service of New York have subjected our proposal – their conditions proposal to approve the transaction. And we've also made our allegations.

Now – so these technical services have requested the Administrative Judge to stop the process until the situation has been clarified in terms of the rumors on the future of Iberdrola but the process continues forward. And on the 27th we will have the oral hearing with the Administrative Judge, but this will not prevent, either before or after that date, that we could retake the negotiations with the technical services with a view to reaching an agreement, which could speed up the timetable envisaged. And the objective is still June of 2008 to finalize that project. Thank you.
Now, we'll have José Sáinz Armada, who will give some details on the accounts.

Thank you. Good mornings. As always, I'm going to take a very quick look at the balance sheet. 2007 has been a year of consolidation. There's been quite a bit of change and, just if we look at the accounts of the different areas. And as clear as possible, I'm going to first going to explain what each area reflects. Once we've finished this session I think the investors – we are at your disposal if you need any further specific clarifications.

As you can see, by the different business lines we've had quite a bit of movement within the Iberdrola Group. So we've defined three major groups of consolidated accounts, each one with a different color.

The first is Iberdrola before ScottishPower, excluding renewables. Here, the liberalized and regulated business in Latin America. Here, we have the same perimeter in 2007. The second group, which is Iberdrola Renovables, includes the whole year of Iberdrola Renovables and the last quarter of ScottishPower renewables. That's the UK part of the business and all of PPM.

And the third group is ScottishPower, includes the business in the UK with except renewables from the 23 April to 31December, and the renewable business in the UK and PPM from 23 April to 30 September. So as you can see, it's a little bit complicated, but we'll try to explain this as clearly as possible.

Before going on to the accounts, I'm going to talk about impact on our balance sheet of the emission rates in 2006 and 2007. Thanks to the conservative policy in our result of our balance sheet, the provisions that we made in 2006, 2007 compensate for the negative impact of the rate.

And finally, the definitive price assigned to the bi-lateralized is €49.43. Since Iberdrola had already talked about €42.43 following the Royal Decree, this brings us to a situation where €149 million additional, which are in the distribution, account. Also the negative impact of the loss of rights means an increase in the provisions for 2006, even the loss of rights that we had originally provided for. And we also increased this by €115 million in terms – this is in the area of generation.

Therefore, as we can see in the gross margin of Distribution compensates for the additional provisions that we had to make. And finally, just a comment that Iberdrola has €361m in terms of the tariff gap compared to 2007.

Now, I'm going to take a quick look at the major aspects of the balance sheet. Once again, this is the legal balance sheet, not the pro forma sheet and so there's different changes and complications in the integration of ScottishPower since 23 April of last year, together with the good behavior of the operations in Latin America. And nine Energy operations accounted for strong growth in all of the lines of the balance sheet.

A growth in EBITDA by 42.4% up to €5.5 billion and net profit by 41.8% to €2.2 billion, just to give an estimate figure of what could have been the pro forma of the Group, on EBITDA this would've grown by 15%, in net profit, by almost 21%.

And now, looking at the different parts of the accounts, the income of the Group increased by 58% to over €17 billion. First of all, given the ScottishPower assets, which are 5.8 billion, second of all, Renovables increased by 37% to 9.5 billion, Latin America and Non-Energy, we have growth up 24 and 33% respectively. Only Energy in Spain fell by 1.1% to 6.2 billion affected by the lower production and lower wholesale electricity prices.

In terms of the provision of the Group 83% -- it grew by 83% and also to the ScottishPower, which was 3.7 billion. In terms of the sales in Latin America Non-Energy sales grew by 27 and 51% compared to a fall of the Energy of 1.8%, given the lower production and the improvement of the mix and lower price of fossil fuels.

Now, in the consolidated the gross margin rose by 48% reaching €8.2 billion. And ScottishPower together have 1.98 billion. And their gross margin of Energy in Spain grew by 3.6% to €3.6 billion, compared to a fall in the first nine months of the year by 2%, thanks to a growth of 17% in this business over the last quarter.

The Latin American business and the non-energy maintained growth in 2007, and by 20.4 and 18.3% respectively. Renovables increased its gross margin by 18.3% to reaching €8.2 billion. Net operational costs grew by 35% reaching €2.4 billion. This, as the Chairman pointed out, is growth of almost eight points lower than the growth of gross margin. ScottishPower contributed €5.7 billion to these expenses. Renovables 2.4 billion, also point out that the Group that we've called Iberdrola, the costs fell by 3.4% to €1.68 billion, thanks for the fall in the personnel costs by 17%, given the positive impact of the pre-retirement plan that was implemented in 2006, and compensates for the increasing cost of extra outsourcing by 15.6%.

Now in terms of attributes we have a strong growth for two reasons. First, and the most important, is because as the deduction for that €115 million for emissions was accounted as an added tax. And the second, in 2006, we had an environmental profit which we didn't have this year for €78 million. And so once we've deducted these impacts this would be -- things are growing as the rest of the company consolidated result is 41.2% to €5.3 billion. And the inclusion of ScottishPower provides €1.3 billion. And we should also point out that in terms of the growth of EBITDA in Spain in the last quarter, which had fallen by 7%, grew by 2% to €2.246 billion.

In Latin America in Non-Energy business generated -- continued to grow in 2007, 25.3 and 14.5%, Renovables grew as well to €5.69 billion in Latin America. The EBIT grew by 39% to €3.6 billion, just under the growth of EBITDA. Given the increase of 49% of the amortizations and provisions, which is really broken down to the growth of amortization of 52.8% and provisions by 29.2%.

The increase in amortizations of €55 billion is broken down into three parts. One, 148 million for the increase in assets and operations due to the investments of the Group. 441 million which are the result of the operation of ScottishPower of which 209 correspond to PPA. And three, the amortization of the Generation assets of both Groups, ScottishPower had a useful life for the combined cycle of 35 years, and Wind power for 25 years, while Iberdrola had 30 and 20 respectively. So we decided to maintain the ScottishPower criteria and cycles and the Iberdrola end part, so this means an improvement of 37 million in amortizations.

The increase in provisions by €60 million corresponds to the 24 million in Iberdrola and €36 million more from the participation of ScottishPower to the consolidated Group. And provisions also includes provisions non-recurring, which can be quantified in more than 100 and some million euros of the total amount for provisions. The financial results were €901 million, 73.6% higher than the 2006 figure, given the increase in the average volume of the debt, around €20 billion, especially debt in pounds, which higher interest rates than the euro for the purchase of ScottishPower, which was almost doubling our debt, and an increase in the interest rates from 4.4 to 5.1%.

Before tax profit grew by almost 30% to €3.98 billion. This growth is just a little lower than EBIT, given the increased financial cost that compensated by the non-recurring costs, which was 41% to €2.61 billion, basically, through the sale of 3% of the electricity grid, and for the sale of buildings. And in terms of the equivalency figures, we had the lower participation of participating companies in 2007 compared to 2006.

The net profit, therefore, grew by 42% reaching €2.35 billion. This increase is greater than the profit before tax, given the lower tax rate in 2007 compared to 2006; the tax rate which we estimate will be maintained over the upcoming years. The reason is basically because the state rate went from 35 to 32.5% and next year it will go from 32.5 to 30%. Secondly, the regional regulatory does not reduce -- which is from 32 to 28%, and the tax rate of ScottishPower is around 30% and will fall to 28%.

And finally, both in the regional legislation and in Latin America we've had deductions for investment. Also, in 2006, the rate was higher than normal because we had greater deductions in futures for that, 35% down to 30%. We should also point out, finally, the strong growth of 46% of the funds generated through operations which is close to €4 billion.

Well, looking at the results of our business, let's look at the Liberalized Business Spain. We include commercial Generation and the non-regulated Gas. First of all, there's a drop of 26.8% of the pool price. There's a change in the mix in the system, an increase of production of 3.3% and a 4% in Hydro electricity. And there's a reduction of the fuel costs and CO2 costs. The provisioning of fuel has gone down by 12% and we have improved the rest of the mix.

Secondly, we have improved the production and ordinary regime because there is a lower nuclear production due to the loads in Coventes and Banda Yosa and a better utilization of the mixed cycles. So we have reduced the margin. The gas business is improving and it compensates the lower wholesale prices.

This has meant that there has been a gross margin fall of 23.6% to €1.995 billion, due to lower prices and production. This has been compensated by the commercial business and by the gas business, and a reduction of the storage cost. The EBITDA has gone down to €1.995 billion. This means that we have now an EBITDA of 1.250 billion. This has been influenced because there is a lower capacity payment of 95 million and a claw back of €149 million. And Iberdrola, contrary to other companies, looks at distribution and not only generation, so these two impacts mean €144 million.

In Renovables, the Group installed capacity as a whole reaches 7.704 billion megawatts and the Group Production 13,309 gigawatts, which is 69% more. In Spain, we have 59% of our installed capacity. And concerning the production, 50% is produced in Spain and 31% in the United States. The gross margin has increased by 18.3% and our EBITDA has increased by 1.3%, achieving €563 million.

The exchange of tariff meter means that it's difficult to compare the evolution. The expenses are determined by the international rate of growth and by the restructuring emerging cost that has an influence on -- in 2007, but they won't be recurrent in the years to come. During the presentation on Renovables, we'll talk about this again.

The gross margin is up by 83.8% to €1.6 billion. This is due to increase of our gross margin by 83.8% to €1.6 billion. This is due to increase of our gross margin by 83.8% to €1.6 billion. As a consequence of these increases, we have increased our EBITDA. This is due to the change in Royal Decree 2006 and 2007. Furthermore, we must add 200 million of costs that we had when we started purchasing on the market a year ago. And then we -- instead of having €43, we have now 42.5.
Secondly, we must stress the net operating cost that goes down by 10.5%, because we've improved our efficiency and we have organized our retirement fund.

The contribution of ScottishPower to the Group, concerning the gross margin since the April 23, amounted to €1.7 billion; 86% coming from the United Kingdom and the rest of it from PPM. Concerning the EBITDA, we have €1.1 billion, 105 from the United Kingdom and 122 from the United States. We have used derivatives in our Gas business, and this means that we have a future price, which now we'll have to evaluate this on the market. €122 billion were indicated as a profit; 60% of them in the United Kingdom. ScottishPower contributes 24.4% of Group EBITDA.

Our business in Latin America is growing. Our EBITDA grows by 25.3% to €889 million, in spite of the negative effect of the dollar devaluation vis-à-vis 2006, excluding the impact of the rate of exchange, otherwise we would have increased by 25 -- 28%. The increase of our capacity and the increase of our production is -- and the cost and efficiency control have enabled us to obtain these excellent results. The gross margin grows by 16% more than the operating net growth, because the gross margin increases by 20% and the net operating expenses by 4% and our EBITDA represents 16% of the Group.

In Brazil and Mexico we have a good rate of growth. Our EBITDA has increased; this is mainly due to the tariff increase as well as the increase of demand by 6%, and the reduction of our loss. This improvement of our gross margin and the reduction of margin has enabled us to achieve an EBITDA of €529 million.

In Mexico and Guatemala there's more production; an increase of 46.7% since we have now Tamaz and there is a good availability of the plant and we have a good increase of our gross margin and of our operating results. We have achieved an EBITDA of €360 million, in spite of the 9.1% drop of the exchange rate.
The EBITDA in Non-Energy plus Engineering has increased by 14.5% to €486 million. This is driven by our Engineering and Real Estate results, as I shall explain later on.

The good development of these two businesses compensate the contribution of IBV. Our Real Estate business is doing well, in spite of the problems we have in the real estate sector at the moment. This doesn't affect so much our business because we've always been very cautious.

Our business is very diversified because we manage soils and we sell properties, but this enables us to face this storm. Furthermore, we have managed to manage properly our costs; our EBITDA increases up to €190 million. Our gross margin achieves €213 million. We have achieved an NNAV of €1.4 million, which is an increase of 5.3% vis-à-vis 2006.

Concerning our Engineering and Construction business, we have achieved €860 million in 2007. We have works portfolio, which means that we'll have some guaranteed future. Our gross margin has increased by 93.5% and we've achieved €197 million and our EBITDA is over €62 million.

Now, let's talk about the leverage and financing. The financial debt represents €20 million, which is 55% more than last year, but our equity has increased by €10 billion and we've achieved €27 billion, which means an increase of 166%. Our leverage has improved tremendously from 54.3% to 41%, so we'll be able to make all these investments that were included in our strategy call plan.

Concerning the financial ratios, the FFO over net debt has improved from 22.5 to 23.8% and we have improved our RCF over net debt from 16.4 to 17.3%. Concerning the liquidity, we have a liquidity of over 11.6 billion, which means that we shall be in a position to develop our strategic plan in 2008 and we'll have more liquidity at the end of the year.
Now, I'll give the floor to our Chairman for the conclusions.

Well, thank you very much, Pepe. As a conclusion, let me stress that in 2007 this has been the take-off year for Iberdrola. We had a rate of growth of 40% in the main businesses and Iberdrola is now another company; it's a different company.

We have an EBITDA of over €5.5 million and a net profit over €2.350 billion. The results come from international investments, 50% of them. We've managed to develop our traditional business, but also new businesses. We have diversified our currency and business risks. In the years to come we'll create more value in a sustainable manner, thanks to our strategic plan for 2008 and 2010.

In these circumstances, the year 2008 will mean a strong rate of growth in all our areas; in Spain, Latin America, ScottishPower and Iberdrola Renovables. We're going to increase our installed capacity and our production. In particular, Iberdrola Renovables is going to commission 2,000 megawatts more in 2008. 208 are already built and 1,245 are under construction at the moment.

The energy prices will increase during the first months of year 2008 and will keep increasing during the rest of the year, taking into account the evolution of the prices of the major raw materials. We'll keep working, trying to improve our efficiency. Synergies will become important, thanks to the integration with ScottishPower, with our Scottish friends and the exchange of best practices in the Group.

Last, but not least, in 2008 we'll have a full year of work in ScottishPower and, according to our estimates, during the third term of the year we'll have with us Energy East. We'll be able this year to have a net profit in 2010 of €3.5 billion, thanks to our investments of more than €24 billion. We'll make it maintaining our financial strength.

I'd like to stress the growth model that we have. In this growth model we take into account all the interest groups of the Company. In 2007, the shareholders have managed to have a total profitability of 28.8%, which means that the accumulated total return since the year 2000 achieves 250%. The employees now belong to a stronger and more international Group.

As a result of it, the training hours have exceeded 800,000, with an investment of €54 million. We have increased our measures for the consolidation of our family and labor life in Spain. We've developed it thanks to a new framework of labor relations, which means that these measures could be implemented in a compatible manner with productivity increase as we did it in Spain. We have increased our commitment with our customers through network investments.

In 2007, we have invested more than €1.3 billion and we have improved the quality in all the countries where we operate. In our societies we have -- all the societies have benefited from it. We have purchased more than €5.5 billion. This has meant more wealth to our providers in the different autonomous communities in Spain, in Scotland, in the United Kingdom, but also in the United States and in Latin America.
Concerning research and development, we have invested more than €65 million. Last, but not least, we have dedicated €50 million to different social projects in the world.

Our strategic plan is a project that aims at creating sustainable value for all. It is a win-win success model. During the last weeks we've -- there have been many support statements to our Iberdrola project, and I would like to thank the shareholders, the trade unions, the business associations, the different autonomous local, national and international institutions. All these statements are the results of the excellent relations that we have with all of them.

I would like to stress that this Company will be able to keep growing and respond to this support with just one project, our strategic plans for the year 2008/2010. We have a strong balance sheet, so we'll be able to keep financing our investment and we have a highly capacitated human team. We've been working as a private Company for more than 100 years. So it can be said very clearly that Iberdrola has become a world giant. We are champion in Europe, in Spain, in America and in the rest of the world, both in terms of growth and in terms of profitability.
Now, we'll have a coffee break and then we'll look at Renovables and the Q&A. So, we'll have a 10-minute short break now.
Please sit down. Thank you.

We are going to start following session. I'll give the floor to our CEO in Renovables, and he's going to inform us about the operational data. Then the Financial Director will mention the financial data of the company.

Good morning, and thanks for being with us for the presentation of these results for 2007. In -- the year 2007 has been a very special year for Iberdrola, because we have managed to integrate all the assets of our -- the thee legs of our company. In Renovables, we've integrated the teams that are part and parcel of these companies and we -- our company has been listed at the end of the year.

We have managed to achieve our targets in 2007. At the end of the year we had installed a capacity of 7,704MW, which is an increase of 19.5%. We have managed to maintain the number of installations and we have under construction 1,373 megawatts at the end of the year 2007, which will help us to achieve our target of 2,000 MW.

In 2007, we have increased the number of the projects up to 42,000MW. We have increased our production in our vis-à-vis 2006 by 14%, in spite of the fact that the last quarter was very bad because there was very little wind. And we have an EBITDA of €777 million, which means that the contribution of the Wind business in Spain amounts to 60%. And prices were not so good in 2007, but there is a changing trend in 2008. This is true for January and also for February.

We've achieved 7,700MW, this is a landmark because we are -- we have now about 1,400 under construction. In Spain, we have installed more than 600,000 – 600MW, which means an increase of 15.5% vis-à-vis 2006. In the United States we have increased by 26.7% our Wind Farms from 2006. In the rest of the world we have an increase of 46.5% and we have installed 103 additional megawatts.

Concerning production, the production has achieved 14,708GW. As I said, this means an increase of 14.3%, vis-à-vis 2006. 48% of this production is in Spain, more than 7MWh, which is an increase vis-à-vis 2006 of 6.7%. During the last quarter -- if the last quarter had been as good as the rest of the year, in terms of wind, our production would have meant 700 more gigawatts. In other words, our increase would have been 16 to 17%, which would have been very similar to the increase of our installed capacity in 2006.

The United States represents 36% of our -- 26% of our production, which is an increase vis-à-vis 2006. This is in line with our additional installed capacity. In the United Kingdom, the production has been more or less the same. This is due to a drop of production that represents 3%, because there was a security -- non-recurring security outage. In the rest of the world, there's been an increase of 43.3%, which is in line with our additional installed capacity.

When we made the presentation of our bid, we said where our basic appeal is, we wanted to grow. And one of these bases is the value of the quality of our pipeline. During the last quarter, we have increased our pipeline by about 800 MW. This means an increase of more than 1,100 MW. Since, during this quarter, we have installed 300,000 MW more. This has been in Spain and in United States. This has happened in very relevant segments where we can be very successful in our pipeline, which is the highly confident sector where we have an increase of 500 MW. As you can see, there is a difference between 2,882, and we've reached 3,103. We also have an increase in the likely segment, which means that we are in a position to increase our rate of growth and achieve our commitment for the year 2008.

In 2007, there's been a price drop. This has meant a reduction of about 10%. In Spain, this has been a drop of about 12%. On the contrary, in January -- if you look at the prices in January, we have an increase vis-à-vis the average price of 2007 of 16% in all our installations and, in Spain, we're over 26%.
I'll give the floor now to our Financial Director.
Thank you, Xabier.

In the legal result page, balance sheet includes only the results from the last quarter of the business from the United States and the UK from ScottishPower. And to facilitate understanding of this balance sheet, we have a pro forma balance sheet that includes the results for the entire year of all of the Renovables sections of Iberdrola. In other words, the annual results of the old Iberdrola Renovables, and those results from the US and UK renewable assets of ScottishPower and an analysis of this consolidated balance sheet is based on the pro forma from 2007 and 2006 to the bid. And the legal balance sheet is what you see here on this next slide, and reflects an increase of EBITDA by 1.3% to €5.6 billion and net results of €170 million.

In terms of the pro forma balance sheet, that's on the next slide, and you see EBITDA of €777.3 million, and that's below the pro forma by 7.7%, affected by the lower prices in Spain, the lower production in the last quarter and the effect of the depreciation of the dollar and the pound, as I'll explain further later. The estimate will be depend on different variables. It will depend on the future prices due to and on our production structure in 2008. It will depend if the year is wet or not, or it will be or dry. According to our estimates, we should have a gross impact between 300 and €400 million.
Danny Bouier from Raymond James is asking about the level of our pipeline or portfolio at the end of 2007.
Our limit is five.
And Luis Aranaz, we have another question. What will be the dividend that you're going to put before the General Assembly?

We've had during many years a dividend policy of about 77%. What I expect to say to the Board, and I hope this is going to be submitted to the General Shareholders' Meeting, is no change vis-à-vis the past.
Can you give an initial valuation of the new Royal Decree concerning distribution?

This Royal Decree was approved and it introduces a few improvements vis-à-vis the previous Decree. Now, we implement the investment estimates on the basis of the data of each company. Our estimate for the year 2008 is that this Royal Decree will mean an improvement of our own contribution in the regulated network of about 6%. This would mean about €80 million.

Last, but not least, Miguel Medina [Deutsche Bank] is putting two questions on Renovables. What does this non-recurrent security outage means in the United Kingdom? And we would like to know about an appeal that has been made by the government of Galicia in Spain.
Keith will answer this question.

We had a one-off issue in the UK, a fault on one turbine resulted in the collapse of the machine. The investigation showed that it was a one-off fault, not a recurring error. All the machines are now back up and running and all of our portfolio is back up and running.

Concerning Galicia, we are partner in Galicia, we'll have different activities and we'll follow the rules of the game. We have created a company which -- and Junta de Galicia is also a member of that company.

So we're going to conclude. Concerning the pending technical questions, we'll send you afterwards the information. Thanks again, I hope that the year 2008 will be a good year, with a good rate of growth. And I hope that this will confirm that we have a good project ahead. Thank you.
